question.title: Is there a way to run Eclipse clean up without using the GUI, aka in headless mode?
question.body:
I'm looking for a way to apply Eclipse Java cleanup rules (not just code formatting) to a set of .java source files from the command line. Specifically, I want to replicate the effect of Eclipse's Source > Clean Up operation (which can apply rules like removing unused imports, imports reordering, adding missing annotations, converting loops to enhanced for-loops, etc.) using a predefined Eclipse cleanup profile, xml or epf that contains cleanup rules like:

cleanup.add_generated_serial_version_id=false
cleanup.add_missing_annotations=true
cleanup.add_missing_deprecated_annotations=true
cleanup.add_missing_methods=false
cleanup.add_missing_nls_tags=false
cleanup.add_missing_override_annotations=true

The behavior I'm looking for is something like running the formatter application from the command line Running the Formatter Application

Also trying to find a way to apply code templates programmatically like adding copyright comments at the beginning of the files using exported Eclipse template.

question_comments.body: @aled I don't know what you mean by "right tool", but the Eclipse clean-ups are already available in other tools. They are designed to be used without the UI of the Eclipse IDE (like most things, the implementation is split into a core and a UI part).
@howlger I don't doubt it. I'm just saying it doesn't mean it is the right tool.
@aled Eclipse provides a couple of operations that can also be run headless, e.g. formatting .java files (as already mentioned in the question).
@cup I highly doubt you can do cleanup.add_missing_override_annotations=true with sed or batch scripts.
As far as I know, this does not yet exist. Please consider to implement and contribute it to Eclipse.
On Linux, you could use a combination of a batch script and sed to insert the copyright comments..  On Windows, you can do this with a simple batch/powershell script.
I would recommend to search for a tool that is designed for headless operation. It is likely tools like Maven or Gradle have plugins for similar operations.
